author: @user-np8mg5yg9n
text: Hi, Josh. Nice to meet you! I am Tai from Taipei, Taiwan. From the video you mentioned in @7:42, can we say that the probability of a random dot on a random line is equal to the proportion of a line to the 2-D plain, which is the area of a line/area of a plain = 0/1? As we are interested in the probability of a random dot on a random line, it's actually the same as asking the chance of the dot on the line/the chance of the dot on the whole plain. As a line is 1-D, and the plain is 2-D, the proportion is 0. Hence, the probability of a random dot on a random line is equal to 0.

text: Would you (@statquest) be able to answer these 4 questions intuitively?  Choose one of the following options for these four statements a = True b = False c = "We can't be sure."  1. If when x increases, y always increases, Pearson's correlation will be always be 1. 2. If when x increases by 1, y always increases by 3, Pearson's correlation will always be 1. 3. If when x increases by 1, y always decreases by 5, Pearson's correlation will always be -1. 4. If when x increases by 1, y increases by 3 times x, Pearson's correlation will always be 1.

author: @mastervim5946
text: great series, but in this one, unfortunately misleading in graphics in later part - the correlation is being conflated with the slope of the line. in the earlier part of the video there are scenes where you can have corr=1 with small positive slope. In the later, a gradual increase in correlation towards 1 is shown together with a gradual movement of the slope towards 1. Better way would be to fix the slope, and have the correlation vary, by "diffusing" the plotted measurements. That would complement the earlier part of the video I think, and make the point that the two properties (slope, correlation) vary independently of one another.  p.s. unsure if the above is due to the possibility of not being able to have a weak correlation with a slope of 1, as it seems you can't have "no correlation" without a slope of 0 or undefined.

author: @andreibarbulescu7812
text: Very well explained! However, there is one thing that may be a bit confusing.  In your explanation of how correlation indicates the fit of the model, the better fit models (stronger correlation) also have a steeper slopes. I guess this is not necessarily the case. A linear model may have a steep slope (mean Y changes a lot with a 1 unit change in X) but the correlation between X and Y could still be weak if there is a lot of variability in Y around each of the [mean Y] predicted by the model, for fixed values of X. Basically a model with a large coefficient of X that has a bad fit to the data. In the case of the multivariate model, If X had a large coefficient (slope) relative to the other variables in the model, I guess this would indicate that X explains more of the variation in Y than the other variables in the model (i.e. Y will change most when changing X, according to the model), but still there could be a lot of variation in Y that is not explained by the model at all (not so good fit). Thus, the slope indicates the relative contribution of X to explaining variability in Y, but only variability that is explained by the model. The correlation coefficient (squared) indicates the proportion of total variability in Y that is explained by the model (containing only X in this case).

author: @statquest
text: NOTE: Although I do not mention it by name in the video, this StatQuest covers Pearson's Correlation Coefficient. Unfortunately, this did not occur to me until after I posted the video, otherwise I would have mentioned it at least 20 times...so maybe it's better the way it turned out. ;)  Support StatQuest by buying my book The StatQuest Illustrated Guide to Machine Learning or a Study Guide or Merch!!! https://statquest.org/statquest-store/

author: @SevenRavens007
text: Still getting this clear in my mind. ..At 13:11 you say that adding data (and a decreased p value) increases our confidence in our guess.  I think this may be misleading because it suggests that b smaller p values mean more accurate guesses.  I would rather say that smaller  p value means more confidence that we are accurately seeing the QUALITY of the guesses we can make (not the guess itself, which is indicated by the correlation value). So with a weak correlation,  smaller p value means I am more certain that there is a weak relationship and that my guess will be poor I hope that makes sense.  Thanks for a great series

author: @suenwynne
text: Thank you for making theses videos, I benefit a lot from them! But I've got a question here. From my understanding in class, it always mentions that covariance does not mean there is a cause and effect relationship between the two variables, while a correlation does. So even though a variable covaries with another, it does not necessarily mean there is a correlation between the two. I can't see this part being explained in this video, and to me, from the video, it seems like correlation is just easier to interpret a relationship than covariance, it does not make it an establishment of a cause and effect relationship. Can you explain this part more? Sorry for my broken English and Thank you in advance!
